I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation National Single Window Project will 
help Maldives implement a national single window (NSW) system that is designed (i) to interface 
with the systems of existing cross-border regulatory agencies (CBRAs); the Malé seaport system, 
the Velana International Airport system; and (ii) to address the key bottlenecks to international 
trade procedures. The project will establish and make operational an automated NSW system for 
international  trade,  and  develop  capacity  building  and  competency  on  NSW  operations. 
Coordinated border management will be enabled as the NSW system integrates the control 
requirements of government agencies, including initial permit applications, filing of declarations, 
coordinated inspections, and integrated release of cargo. 
 
2.  The  project  will  have  three  outputs:  (i)  NSW  system  for  international  trade  and 
reengineered trade processes established; (ii) capacity of relevant agencies and private sector 
users, including women, to utilize the NSW developed; and (iii) high-level technologies to support 
NSW and trade facilitation pilot tested. The government has requested (i) a concessional loan of 
$5.0 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, and (ii) a grant of $5.0 million from ADB’s 
Special Funds resources (Asian Development Fund) to help finance the project.  
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  The  transaction  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  assist  Maldives  in  establishing  and 
operationalizing the NSW system for international trade successfully. It will help in building 
capacity  of  stakeholders  and  in  preparing  guidance  tools  that  will  support  sustainable 
implementation and raise awareness among stakeholders. The successful implementation of an 
NSW  requires  several  steps,  including  establishing  appropriate  governance  structures, 
harmonizing data, developing a legal framework, selecting a business model and operator for the 
NSW, setting up requisite hardware and software, developing an integrated risk management 
system, and building capacity of CBRA officials and private sector service providers. 
 
4.  The planning and implementation of the NSW includes wide-ranging changes that may 
pose challenges in view of the limited capacity and experience of Maldives in implementing major 
trade facilitation reforms. The NSW will cover five CBRAs; Maldives Ports Limited; Maldives 
Airports Company Limited; and private sector stakeholders such as importers, exporters, customs 
brokers, shipping agents, airlines, freight forwarders, and bond operators. Each of the agencies 
and stakeholders have its own business processes and information technology systems and is at 
a different level of preparedness, compounding the challenges. NSW implementation in other 
countries such as India has highlighted issues related to project management capability, project 
leadership and coordination, and institutional issues. The resolution of project implementation 
challenges is crucial since the NSW environment requires integration of the NSW system with 
multiple stakeholders and their systems. 
 
5.  The TA and the project are included in the country operations business plan for Maldives, 
2019–2021.1 2

B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
6.  Output 1: Legal framework required for effective implementation of the national 
single window finalized. The TA will support the preparation of (i) a draft report on legal issues 
related to the identification, authorization, and authentication of electronic transactions; (ii) a draft 
report on the administrative and standard operating procedures required for CBRAs and private 
sector stakeholders to implement the NSW, including the interim procedures to be followed prior 
to the entry into force of the legal framework; and (iii) a final draft report on the legal framework 
required for NSW implementation covering electronic transactions, data protection, and cyber 
security and electronic payments. For preparing the reports on the legal framework, the TA will 
support the conduct of legal gap analysis and assist in drafting legal amendments and procedures 
relevant to implementation of the NSW, covering provisions related to identification, authorization, 
and authentication of electronic transactions; and admissibility of electronic evidence in judicial 
and enforcement proceedings. To help introduce the legislative amendments to the daily NSW 
operations, the TA will develop standard operating procedures and other relevant tools. To 
support the success of the project, the TA will help conduct training on implementing the updated 
legal framework. 
 
7.  Output  2:  Project  design  and  implementation  requirements  developed  and 
monitored. The TA will (i) support the institutional structure set up for establishing the NSW (such 
as the NSW steering committee) in developing and monitoring the implementation plan, (ii) 
prepare a report with recommendations on the sequencing the NSW rollout, and (iii) advise on 
the achievement of priority activities during implementation. The TA will help the NSW steering 
committee in monitoring the progress in establishing the NSW; advise the NSW operator and 
implementing agencies on any problem areas, improvements, and course corrections needed; 
and provide technical advisory services for smooth implementation of the NSW. The TA will 
recommend sequencing for a phased rollout of the NSW services and review progress of 
milestones against the implementation plan. This output will also require extensive stakeholder 
interactions. 
 
8.  Output 3: Capacity of relevant agencies and private sector users, including women, 
to utilize the national single window developed. The TA will support the formulation of a 
capacity development plan, and the conduct of capacity building activities and organizational 
change management to help implement and make operational the NSW system. The TA will (i) 
prepare a report on the capacity development plan for project stakeholders; (ii) prepare CBRAs 
for better adoption and successful implementation of the NSW through reorientation; (iii) prepare 
a draft handbook to guide and assist the CBRAs and private sector entities in operating and 
utilizing the NSW; and (iv) conduct workshops and interactions for the private sector stakeholders, 
including women, to prepare them for effective utilization of the NSW. Representatives from the 
NSW steering committee will be supported with workshops and first-hand exposure to the project 
as well as the technical aspects related to a NSW. The TA will prepare and assist in the execution 
of  a  detailed  change management  strategy to  enable the  CBRAs  and  other  implementing 
agencies to implement the NSW in a sustainable manner. To promote better understanding and 
standardized implementation, the TA will help in preparing handbooks and manuals for the 
engaging staff of all the implementing agencies. The TA will also develop the capability to 
manage, maintain, and carry out future enhancements in the NSW system (as well as the 
interfaces), and to fulfill the service-level requirements. 
 
9.  Output 4: High-level technologies to support the national single window and trade 
facilitation pilot tested. The TA will support the NSW steering committee and the NSW operator 
in the sustainable development of the NSW system by (i) conducting feasibility studies and pilot

3 
testing of application of cutting-edge technologies relating to NSW operation, (ii) organizing 
workshops and conferences for the stakeholders to raise awareness and enhance knowledge on 
the applications and features of these technologies, and (iii) identifying benefits and risks to be 
resolved upon application of the technologies to the NSW system. The TA will produce prototypes 
and test applications of technologies, mainly blockchain and e-payment gateway platforms, for 
trade facilitation. Blockchain, which enables users to track the shipping of items and to record all 
related documentation history on its distributed ledger without a chance of falsification, has the 
potential to be adopted as an NSW operation system in the future. An e-payment gateway 
platform functions as a hub and simplifies the processing of payment transactions for electronic 
services, which will be a component of the NSW. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.0 million, of which (i) $0.5 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6); and (ii) $0.5 million will be financed 
on a grant basis by the High-Level Technology Fund3 and administered by ADB. 
 
11.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of staff, office and housing 
accommodation, office supplies, secretarial assistance, domestic transportation, and other in-kind 
contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to 
finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  The TA will be implemented from June 2019 to June 2023 with the Ministry of Economic 
Development (MED) as the lead implementing agency. ADB will administer the TA, led by the 
South Asia Department’s Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination Division, which will 
recruit consultants and procure goods. 
 
13.  All TA disbursements will be made following ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Limited  international  bidding  or  direct 
contracting with a specialized supplier and installer might be considered. National competitive 
bidding and shopping methods would be considered for procurement of office equipment. All 
procurements under the TA will be made following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and its associated staff instructions. 
 
14.  The government’s implementation arrangements will follow those of the ongoing projects. 
The government formed the National Trade Facilitation Committee (NTFC), which is chaired by 
the minister of the MED. The NSW steering committee set up under the NTFC will oversee and 
monitor project implementation. The executing agency is the Ministry of Finance, a member of 
the Economic and Youth Council. The implementing agencies are the MED; Maldives Customs 
Service; five more CBRAs, all of which are members of the NTFC; Maldives Port Limited; Maldives 
Airports Company Limited; and the Maldives Monetary Authority.
